content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a concise summary of the section's title and its purpose. The "National Collegiate Athletics Accountability Act" or the "NCAA Act" highlights the significant amount of funding institutions of higher education receive annually under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, including Federal Pell Grants. This funding is crucial for providing grants, loans, and work-study funds to students. Athletic programs at institutions of higher education generate significant revenue through various sources, totaling approximately $6.1 billion. This revenue includes funds from ticket sales, media rights, alumni contributions, and association distributions. The Committee on Sports Medicine of the American Academy of Pediatrics classified sports based on contact, impact, or injury likelihood. Contact/collision sports include boxing, football, soccer, etc. Limited-contact/impact sports include baseball, basketball, gymnastics, etc. SEC. 2. PROGRAM PARTICIPATION AGREEMENTS. Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include requirements for annual baseline concussion testing of student athletes in intercollegiate athletic programs. The amendment to Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 includes requirements for formal administrative hearings, appeals, and due process procedures for student athletes and institutions before enforcing any remedy for policy violations. The amendment to Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 ensures that athletically related student aid for contact/collision sport athletes must be guaranteed for up to 4 years, irrevocable due to athletic skill or injury, and allows institutions to pay stipends to student athletes. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics is established. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics is established to review issues related to the interaction of athletics and academics in higher education, including student success, academic integrity, graduation rates, and academic eligibility standards. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics reviews issues related to the interaction of athletics and academics in higher education, including student success, academic integrity, graduation rates, and standards of academic eligibility for student athletes. It also examines the financing of intercollegiate athletics, such as revenue sources, expenditures, financial transparency, and the ability of institutions to finance athletics. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics reviews issues related to the interaction of athletics and academics in higher education, including student success, academic integrity, graduation rates, and standards of academic eligibility for student athletes. It also examines the criteria for financial disbursements, rules on earnings and benefits for student athletes, tax regulations, and federal judicial decisions affecting compensation for student athletes. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics reviews issues related to student athletes, including recruitment, retention, oversight, governance, health and safety protections, due process, and any other relevant issues. The Commission will develop recommendations based on the review and analysis of these issues, with a membership of 17 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House of Representatives, and other officials. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics consists of 17 members appointed by various officials, including three members appointed by the minority leader of the House of Representatives, three members appointed by the majority leader of the Senate, and three members appointed by the minority leader of the Senate, each including one member from the respective chamber and two individuals who are not Members of Congress. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics consists of 17 members appointed by various officials, including individuals specially qualified by education, training, or experience. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled as per original appointments. The Chair is elected by members, who serve without pay but are reimbursed for necessary expenses. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics appoints a staff director and necessary personnel to carry out functions, with compensation not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Meetings are held as needed. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chair or majority of members, with the first meeting within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, delegate actions, and access information from US departments and agencies. The Commission has the authority to request information from US departments and agencies, use the United States mails, and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. A report of its findings must be submitted to the President and Congress within 1 year of the first meeting. The Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics will submit a report to the President and Congress within 1 year of its first meeting. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. Definitions include the Commission as the Presidential Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics and an institution of higher education as defined by the Higher Education Act of 1965.
